study_goal: The researchers aimed to review methods for extracting and analyzing chlorogenic acid using molecularly imprinted polymers (MIPs) and evaluate their effectiveness.
results_summary: The study surveyed conventional and newly developed methods for preparing MIPs to extract chlorogenic acid, highlighting their advantages, limitations, and strategies for improving efficiency in complex samples. Advanced imprinting methods were also presented to enhance adsorption capacity, sensitivity, and selectivity.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on analytical methods, not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on extraction techniques).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a hydrogel embedded with chlorogenic acid/carboxymethyl chitosan nanoparticles (CGA/CMCS-HAMA) in treating burn wounds by addressing oxidative stress, inflammation, and promoting healing.
results_summary: The hydrogel demonstrated stability, degraded by over 50% by day 20, effectively scavenged ROS, inhibited lipid peroxidation and ferroptosis, modulated inflammatory factors, and promoted cell adhesion and migration, supporting burn wound healing.
population_specificity: Burn wound patients (specific human or animal model not specified in the abstract).
study_duration: Up to 20 days (based on degradation data)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) in improving spermatogenic dysfunction in rat testis induced by varicocele (VC) and its potential mechanisms, including mitochondrial damage and inflammation.
results_summary: CGA treatment improved seminiferous tubule pathology, increased sperm count, reduced ROS and pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, IL-18), and mitigated mitochondrial damage. It also inhibited the cGAS-STING axis and NLRP3 inflammasome activation, suggesting therapeutic potential for VC-induced infertility.
population_specificity: Male rats with varicocele-induced testicular damage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-tumor effects of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) on cholangiocarcinoma (CCA) and its underlying mechanisms, including its interaction with AKR1B10 and modulation of immune responses.
results_summary: CGA significantly suppressed CCA cell proliferation, migration, invasion, and epithelial-mesenchymal transition while inducing apoptosis and modulating cell cycle progression. It also reduced AKR1B10 expression, suppressed AKT activation, and enhanced anti-tumor immune responses by polarizing macrophages and boosting T-cell cytotoxicity.
population_specificity: Cholangiocarcinoma (CCA) cells, specifically RBE cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether calcium-chlorogenic acid nanoparticles (Ca-CGA NPs) could enhance osteogenic differentiation of BMSCs and promote anti-inflammatory polarization of macrophages to accelerate bone regeneration.
results_summary: Ca-CGA NPs enhanced osteogenic differentiation of BMSCs and promoted macrophage polarization from M1 to M2 phenotype, facilitating bone regeneration in a rat skull defect model.
population_specificity: Rat model (in vivo) and bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (BMSCs) and macrophages (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the inhibitory mechanism and anti-biofilm activity of chlorogenic acid-grafted-chitosan (CS-g-CA) against Pseudomonas fluorescens.
results_summary: CS-g-CA reduced biofilm size, extracellular polymers, motility, and adhesion of P. fluorescens, increased ROS levels, diminished CAT activity, and interfered with quorum-sensing signaling and c-di-GMP synthesis.
population_specificity: Pseudomonas fluorescens (bacterial culture)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) on cognitive impairments, neuroinflammation, and neuronal damage in a mouse model of Sporadic Alzheimer Disease (SAD).
results_summary: CGA treatment significantly alleviated memory deficits, protected against neuronal damage, reduced neuroinflammation, and preserved viable cell counts and BDNF levels in key brain regions.
population_specificity: Male Swiss mice with induced Sporadic Alzheimer Disease (SAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Chlorogenic Acid's potential as a pharmacological adjuvant in cancer treatment, focusing on its ability to combat chemoresistance and mitigate chemotherapy-induced toxicity.
results_summary: The study found that Chlorogenic Acid can overcome resistance to conventional chemotherapeutics and reduce chemotherapy-induced toxicity by effectively scavenging free radicals, based on in vitro and animal studies. It also highlighted CGA's potential as an adjuvant in cancer therapy with drugs like 5-fluorouracil, cisplatin, and others.
population_specificity: In vitro and animal models (specific human population not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chlorogenic acid (CGA) conjugated with PLGA nanomicelles in reducing inflammation and joint damage in a rheumatoid arthritis model.
results_summary: The study found that MTX-PLGA-b-CGA nanomicelles significantly reduced joint swelling, cartilage erosion, and disease severity in a collagen-induced arthritis model, while also lowering pro-inflammatory markers like RANKL and TNF-α.
population_specificity: Collagen-induced arthritis model (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and angiogenic properties of chlorogenic acid (CGA) when grafted into an injectable chitosan hydrogel for treating diabetic chronic wounds.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of chitosan-grafted chlorogenic acid (CS-CGA) demonstrated excellent antibacterial and anti-inflammatory properties, along with antioxidant and angiogenic abilities, making it effective for treating complex bacterial infections in chronic wounds.
population_specificity: Diabetic chronic wounds (specific human population not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the killing effect of chlorogenic acid on drug-resistant R. anatipestifer and its regulatory impact on drug resistance genes.
results_summary: Chlorogenic acid maintained consistent MIC values against both standard and drug-resistant R. anatipestifer strains and increased bacterial sensitivity to doxycycline. It also reversed the expression trends of drug resistance genes in induced strains.
population_specificity: R. anatipestifer strains (standard and clinical isolates)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory effects and mechanisms of Chlorogenic Acid and related compounds on lipid metabolism in OA-induced HepG2 cells and HFD-fed zebrafish.
results_summary: Chlorogenic Acid and related compounds reduced lipid accumulation, triacylglycerol levels, MDA, and ROS while increasing SOD levels. They also modulated lipogenesis-related proteins (FAS, ACC, PPARγ) and increased PPARα expression, suggesting potential benefits for NAFLD.
population_specificity: OA-induced HepG2 cells and HFD-fed zebrafish.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects and mechanisms of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) on porcine parthenogenetic activation (PA) early-stage embryos, focusing on oxidative stress regulation and mitochondrial function.
results_summary: CGA treatment at 50 μM significantly improved cleavage and blastocyst formation rates, enhanced blastocyst quality, promoted zygotic genome activation (ZGA), reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS), increased glutathione levels, and improved mitochondrial function in porcine PA early-stage embryos.
population_specificity: Porcine parthenogenetic activation (PA) early-stage embryos.
study_duration: Duration of the IVC period (specific length not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of chlorogenic acid (CGA) in mitigating LPS-induced cystitis in mice, focusing on voiding behavior and bladder inflammation.
results_summary: Low CGA treatment improved micturition pressure and reduced bladder inflammation and edema in LPS-induced cystitis mice, while high CGA treatment showed adverse effects like prolonged inter-contraction intervals and increased voided volume.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice with LPS-induced cystitis.
effective_dosage: Low and high CGA (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary chlorogenic acid (CGA) supplementation could mitigate heat stress-induced declines in growth performance and liver damage in rabbits.
results_summary: CGA supplementation improved growth performance, enhanced antioxidative capacity, and reduced liver damage markers in heat-stressed rabbits by activating the Nrf2/HO-1 pathway and inhibiting hepatic apoptosis.
population_specificity: New Zealand weaned rabbits under heat stress conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of exogenous chlorogenic acid (CGA) on flavonoid levels, antioxidant capacity, and nutrient growth in *Lonicera japonica* plants.
results_summary: The study found that CGA treatment significantly increased flavonoid levels, upregulated secondary metabolite-related enzyme genes, enhanced antioxidant capacity, and improved nutrient growth indicators in *L. japonica*. Metabolomic analysis revealed notable changes in metabolites, particularly in pathways related to nutrient metabolism and antioxidant production.
population_specificity: *Lonicera japonica* (L. japonica) plants
effective_dosage: Applied via foliar sprays every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday (exact concentration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) in reducing oxidative stress and hippocampal cell loss in a lithium-pilocarpine-induced status epilepticus (SE) model in Wistar rats.
results_summary: CGA (30 mg/kg) significantly reduced hippocampal cell loss (59% in CA3, 48% in hilus) and oxidative stress markers (49% decrease in MDA, 72% decrease in SOD activity) compared to controls, demonstrating neuroprotective effects.
population_specificity: Wistar rats subjected to lithium-pilocarpine-induced status epilepticus.
effective_dosage: 30 mg/kg, administered for three consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a multifunctional hydrogel containing chlorogenic acid (CA) in promoting wound healing, particularly in diabetic wounds, by assessing its antibacterial, antioxidant, and angiogenic properties.
results_summary: The hydrogel demonstrated strong antioxidant capabilities, promoted cell migration and angiogenesis, and accelerated diabetic wound healing by regulating macrophage phenotypes and relieving oxidative stress. It also enabled real-time monitoring of wound healing stages.
population_specificity: Diabetic wound models (in vivo, likely animal models based on liver and tail amputation tests).
effective_dosage: Not specified (CA was loaded into ZIF-8 nanoparticles within the hydrogel).
study_duration: Not specified (study focused on wound healing phases rather than a fixed intervention period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy and mechanisms of action of chlorogenic acid and cinnamaldehyde against breast cancer, with a focus on translational applications.
results_summary: The study found that chlorogenic acid demonstrated efficacy against various molecular subtypes of breast cancer in vitro and in vivo, with multiple mechanisms of action for destroying cancer cells. The abstract highlights its potential as an effective and inexpensive plant-based treatment but calls for further translational research.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cells (in vitro and in vivo models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the mechanism by which chlorogenic acid prevents Duck enteritis virus (DEV) infection and its effects on viral proliferation and pathological damage.
results_summary: Chlorogenic acid significantly reduced DEV load in duck embryo fibroblast cells and duck lymphoid organs, alleviated pathological damage, and inhibited DEV proliferation by regulating the NF-κB signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Duck embryo fibroblast (DEF) cells and 30-day-old ducks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chlorogenic acid could enhance osteoblast proliferation, inhibit osteoclastogenesis, and counteract bone loss in ovariectomized rats.
results_summary: Chlorogenic acid promoted osteoblast proliferation and differentiation, inhibited RANKL-induced osteoclastogenesis, and mitigated bone loss in ovariectomized rats. It also improved bone volume and mechanical properties.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized (OVX) rats, modeling postmenopausal osteoporosis.

study_goal: To investigate whether chlorogenic acid (CGA) alleviates acute kidney injury (AKI) in mice by inhibiting the NLRP3 inflammasome and caspase-1 signaling pathway.
results_summary: CGA treatment improved survival rates, reduced renal pathologies, and lowered levels of kidney injury markers (BUN, Scr, KIM-1) and inflammatory proteins (NLRP3, caspase-1 pathway) in septic mice.
population_specificity: C57Bl/6J mice with CLP-induced sepsis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of exogenous chlorogenic acid (CGA) treatment on quality deterioration of fresh-cut potato slices and the underlying mechanisms involved.
results_summary: CGA treatment effectively retarded browning, suppressed microbial growth, inhibited declines in starch and ascorbic acid, activated the phenylpropanoid pathway, reduced reactive oxygen species accumulation, and enhanced antioxidant enzyme activity and ATP levels.
population_specificity: Fresh-cut potato slices

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effects of Chlorogenic Acid and its potential as a treatment for inflammatory diseases by studying its impact on inflammation-related signaling pathways and cytokine regulation.
results_summary: Chlorogenic Acid demonstrated strong anti-inflammatory effects by modulating NF-κB and Nrf2 signaling pathways, upregulating anti-inflammatory cytokines (IL-4, IL-10, IL-13), and downregulating pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, IL-8). However, clinical application faces challenges, and further research is needed to explore its molecular mechanisms and clinical potential.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or animal studies implied, but not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanism by which Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) protects against cardiac hypertrophy (CH) induced by isoproterenol, focusing on the Wnt/β-catenin signaling pathway.
results_summary: CGA significantly reduced cell surface area and downregulated CH-related markers (ANP, BNP, β-MHC) at mRNA and protein levels. It also modulated the Wnt/β-catenin pathway by increasing GSK-3β expression and decreasing β-catenin, suggesting a protective role against CH.
population_specificity: AC16 cells (human cardiomyocyte cell line) stimulated with isoproterenol.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of chlorogenic acid (CGA) on cardiac hypertrophy and elucidate its underlying mechanisms, focusing on the AMPK/SIRT1 pathway via S1pr1 modulation.
results_summary: CGA treatment reduced cardiac hypertrophy markers, endoplasmic reticulum stress, and apoptosis in ISO-induced models, both in vitro and in vivo, by activating the AMPK/SIRT1 pathway. The protective effects were dose-dependent and reversed by S1pr1 knockdown.
population_specificity: H9c2 myocardial cells and ISO-induced cardiac hypertrophy rat models.
effective_dosage: 10, 50, and 100 μM in vitro; 90 mg/kg/day in vivo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chlorogenic acid could mitigate oxidative stress and neuroprotective effects by regulating thioredoxin expression in ischemic brain injury and glutamate toxicity.
results_summary: Chlorogenic acid reduced ROS and lipid peroxidation levels, mitigated neurological defects, and restored thioredoxin expression in MCAO-induced rats. It also attenuated glutamate-induced neuronal damage by modulating apoptosis-related proteins (bcl-2, bax, cytochrome c, caspase-3) and preserving thioredoxin-ASK1 interaction.
population_specificity: Adult rats with induced middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO) and cultured neurons exposed to glutamate toxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of grafting chlorogenic acid (CA) onto myosin using different techniques and to evaluate its potential as an emulsifier.
results_summary: The UM technique showed the highest CA-binding capacity (80.26 μmol/g myosin) and improved myosin solubility while reducing aggregation. The resulting emulsion exhibited strong oxidation resistance and storage stability.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and chemopreventive potential of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) against ulcerative colitis (UC) and explore novel drug delivery systems to improve its bioavailability.
results_summary: The study found that CGA exhibits significant pharmacological effects, including anti-inflammatory and chemopreventive properties, but suffers from low absorption and poor oral bioavailability. Colon-specific novel drug delivery systems were highlighted as a promising solution to enhance its therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Individuals with ulcerative colitis (UC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chlorogenic acid (CA) could reduce the allergenicity of crayfish tropomyosin and alleviate allergic reactions in a food allergy mouse model.
results_summary: CA effectively reduced tropomyosin's allergenicity by altering its secondary structure and masking its linear epitopes, leading to milder allergic reactions in mice. The study also suggested that CA might up-regulate TLR8, contributing to reduced allergenicity.
population_specificity: Food allergy mouse model (specific to crayfish tropomyosin allergy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of chlorogenic acid as a treatment for microbial contamination in dental unit waterlines (DUWLs).
results_summary: Chlorogenic acid treatment significantly altered the microbial community profile in DUWLs, reducing opportunistic pathogens like Mycobacteria and increasing beneficial bacteria such as Alloprevotella, Roseburia, and Blautia. Functional analysis indicated decreased pathogenicity in the bacterial community after treatment.
population_specificity: Microbial communities in 149 DUWL samples from 5 dental units.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary chlorogenic acid (CGA) on growth performance, immune function, inflammation response, antioxidant capacity, and related mechanisms in common carp.
results_summary: CGA supplementation significantly improved growth performance, immune function, and antioxidant capacity in common carp, while reducing inflammation markers and enhancing intestinal health. The optimal dosage was found to be 400 mg/kg.
population_specificity: Common carp (Cyprinus carpio)
effective_dosage: 0 mg/kg (control), 100 mg/kg, 200 mg/kg, 400 mg/kg, and 800 mg/kg

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the digestive behavior of Chlorogenic Acid (CA) when combined with biomimetic dietary fiber (BDF) and its antioxidant activity.
results_summary: The study found that 41.03% of CA remained in a conjugated form after simulated digestion, influenced by interactions with polysaccharides. The combination of polysaccharides and CA showed synergistic antioxidant effects, likely due to noncovalent interactions like hydrogen bonding.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chlorogenic Acid (CPP) could counteract the oxidative effects of Hydroxyhydroquinone (HHQ) in SAMP8 mice, a model sensitive to oxidative damage.
results_summary: Chlorogenic Acid (CPP) reduced hydrogen peroxide levels in the serum of SAMP8 mice when coexisting with HHQ, demonstrating antioxidative effects. No abnormalities were observed in the CPP-treated group, unlike the HHQ-treated group, which showed signs of oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Senescence-accelerated mouse prone 8 (SAMP8) mice, a model for oxidative stress sensitivity.
interactions: Counteracted oxidative effects of HHQ when coexisting at the rate found in roasted coffee.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of dietary supplements, including chlorogenic acid, for treating retinitis pigmentosa (RP).
results_summary: The study found no high-quality evidence supporting the effectiveness of chlorogenic acid for RP, with most findings derived from secondary outcomes or problematic interpretations. No prominent safety concerns were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with retinitis pigmentosa (RP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) could protect macrophages from damage caused by cefotaxime sodium-resistant Escherichia coli (CSR-EC) infection and explore its effects on the PANoptosis pathway.
results_summary: CGA increased macrophage survival, reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-18, TNF-α, IL-6), decreased ROS generation, and upregulated Nrf-2 expression. It also inhibited key proteins involved in PANoptosis (Caspase-3, -7, -8, -1, GSDMD, NLRP-3, RIPK-3, MLKL).
population_specificity: Cultured macrophages infected with CSR-EC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of natural products, including Chlorogenic Acid, as alternative or complementary therapeutic agents for managing non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Chlorogenic Acid's effects on NASH, only mentioning that natural products from medicinal plants offer potential promise for NASH treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of NASH and natural products)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a water-soluble green coffee bean extract (GCB70®) enriched in chlorogenic acid for healthy weight management and metabolic health improvements.
results_summary: GCB70 supplementation significantly reduced body weight, BMI, waist circumference, plasma leptin, fasting glucose, HbA1c, and TSH levels, with broad-spectrum safety confirmed. The effects were statistically significant and observed in a high percentage of participants.
population_specificity: 105 participants (male and female) with obesity or overweight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chlorogenic Acid, as part of the Altilix® supplement, could improve cardiometabolic parameters in pre-obesity subjects.
results_summary: The study found that Altilix® significantly reduced body weight, improved glycemic and lipid parameters, and enhanced hepatic functionality, carotid-media thickness, and endothelial function after six months of treatment.
population_specificity: Pre-obesity subjects (BMI ≥ 25 and < 30 kg/m2) from a cohort of 50 participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Green Coffee Extract (GCE) and Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) on improving lipid profiles.
results_summary: The study found mixed results regarding the effect of GCE and CGA on lipid profile improvement, with higher dosages and longer durations showing better outcomes, but further research is needed to confirm efficacy and safety.
population_specificity: Not specified (includes clinical trials and animal studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of green coffee bean extract (GCBE) supplementation, which contains chlorogenic acid, on C-reactive protein (CRP) levels.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that GCBE supplementation significantly reduced CRP levels, particularly in non-healthy subjects, at doses ≥ 1000 mg/d and in interventions lasting < 4 weeks. The effect was statistically significant but modest in magnitude.
population_specificity: Non-healthy subjects (dyslipidemia, hypertension, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease) and general populations from included studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chlorogenic Acid and other polyphenols in dried plum influence preosteoblast proliferation and activity in vitro, and whether these compounds improve bone health in vivo and ex vivo.
results_summary: Chlorogenic Acid and related compounds induced preosteoblast proliferation and repressed alkaline phosphatase activity in vitro. In vivo, low-chlorogenic acid prunes and juice concentrate prevented bone mineral density loss in estrogen-deficient rats and restored bone marker levels.
population_specificity: 5-month-old female rats with induced estrogen deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing studies on the effects of chlorogenic acid (CGA) on cognition and neurological health.
results_summary: The review found that CGA consumption is linked to various health benefits, including neuroprotection, anti-inflammatory effects, and reduced risk of neurodegenerative conditions, though no formal, well-controlled studies have been conducted yet.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of pre-clinical and clinical studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how pulsed electric fields (PEF) affect the structure and biological activity of chlorophyll aggregates.
results_summary: PEF treatment altered the microstructure of chlorophyll aggregates, forming smaller particles with enhanced antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activities in vitro. Molecular dynamics simulations confirmed PEF-induced changes, including increased radius of gyration and solvent-accessible surface area, suggesting disaggregation and improved bioactivity.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the responses of Cycas panzhihuaensis to drought, heat, and their combined effects on chlorophyll fluorescence and lipid/fatty acid profiles.
results_summary: The study found that chlorophyll photochemical activity was least impacted by drought and most severely impacted by combined drought-heat stress. Lipid and fatty acid profiles varied significantly under different stress conditions, with notable changes in unsaturation levels and lipid categories.
population_specificity: Cycas panzhihuaensis (an endangered plant species in dry-hot valleys of southwestern China).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how melatonin (MT) mitigates salt stress effects on the photosynthetic efficiency of tomato seedlings, focusing on chlorophyll-related mechanisms.
results_summary: Exogenous MT improved photosynthetic parameters, enhanced PSII reaction center functionality, and restored energy absorption and dissipation under salt stress, while MT synthesis inhibitor p-CPA exacerbated damage.
population_specificity: Tomato seedlings under saline stress conditions in a hydroponic setup.
effective_dosage: 100 μmol·L-1 MT and 100 μmol·L-1 p-CPA, applied via foliar spraying.
study_duration: Six days of salt stress exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of chlorophyll biosynthesis, specifically the activity of POR1 and POR2 genes, in tocopherol (vitamin E) content in maize grain.
results_summary: The study found that reducing chlorophyll biosynthesis (via dark treatment or CRISPR/Cas9 knockout of POR1 and POR2) significantly decreased tocopherol levels in maize embryos, demonstrating a strong dependency of tocopherol synthesis on chlorophyll-derived phytol.
population_specificity: Maize (Zea mays) grain (non-photosynthetic embryo tissue).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of combining natural spinach-derived chlorophylls with water-soluble chlorophyll proteins (WSCPs) as a safe and effective photosensitizer for photodynamic therapy (PDT) in cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found that recombinant WSCPs (chlorophyll-WSCP) were stable, water-soluble, nontoxic, and capable of producing highly reactive singlet oxygen under light irradiation to induce cancer cell death, demonstrating efficacy in a melanoma xenograft mouse model.
population_specificity: In vivo mouse model (melanoma xenografts)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of strigolactones (SLs) in regulating culm sheath senescence by promoting chlorophyll degradation in Bambusa multiplex.
results_summary: The study found a positive relationship between SL content and sheath senescence, with SL analog GR24 reducing chlorophyll content and SL inhibitor Tis108 increasing it. Chloroplast degradation began one day after GR24 treatment, suggesting SLs regulate senescence via chlorophyll degradation.
population_specificity: Bambusa multiplex (bamboo plant) culm sheaths at different developmental stages.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exogenous GR24 and Tis108 treatments used, but exact dosages not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (observations made one day after GR24 treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of hydrogen sulfide (H2S) and methyl jasmonate (MeJA) in alleviating cadmium (Cd) stress in cucumber seedlings, focusing on chlorophyll concentration and degradation.
results_summary: Both H2S and MeJA significantly increased chlorophyll concentration, inhibited chlorophyll degradation, and enhanced chlorophyll fluorescence under Cd stress. They also improved ROS-scavenging capacity and photosynthesis system functionality.
population_specificity: Cucumber seedlings (Cucumis sativus) exposed to cadmium stress.
effective_dosage: Optimal concentrations of NaHS (H2S donor) or MeJA, but exact amounts not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the photodynamic therapy (PDT) efficacy of the chlorophyll derivative CIPp-18 in treating human breast carcinoma (MCF-7) and cervical adenocarcinoma (Hela) cells under normoxic and hypoxic conditions.
results_summary: CIPp-18 induced potent phototoxicity in both cell lines under normoxic and hypoxic conditions, with singlet oxygen playing a major role under normoxia and a ROS-independent mechanism under hypoxia. PDT led to significant loss of membrane permeability, particularly under hypoxia.
population_specificity: Human breast carcinoma (MCF-7) and cervical adenocarcinoma (Hela) cells.
effective_dosage: 2.0 µM CIPp-18 for 3 hours, with NIR light (700 ± 25 nm, 0.36-1.4 J/cm²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of progressive drought stress on the photosynthetic light reactions in tomato plants, focusing on chlorophyll-related mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that drought stress significantly impaired photosynthetic efficiency, damaging PSII and PSI functionality, reducing electron transport, and downregulating key genes (PetE and PetF) involved in electron transfer.
population_specificity: Tomato plants (Solanum lycopersicum)
effective_dosage: Not applicable (drought stress levels: 100%, 75%, 50%, and 25% of field capacity)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of climate change on chlorophyll-a (Chl-a) concentrations in water resources, particularly in the Latyan Dam and Tehranpars Water Treatment Plant (TWTP).
results_summary: The study found that Chl-a concentrations in the TWTP effluent were only slightly influenced by climate change, but significant increases in streamflow were projected, raising concerns about water quality and flooding risks. Fuzzy regression models FGR1, FGR3, and FGR4 performed best in modeling Chl-a output.
population_specificity: Water resources in the Jajrood watershed, specifically the Latyan Dam and Tehranpars Water Treatment Plant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of nitrogen doses on chlorophyll content, agronomic traits, and stomatal characteristics in wheat cultivars.
results_summary: Increasing nitrogen doses significantly increased chlorophyll content, seed yield, plant height, and stomatal characteristics, with the highest chlorophyll content observed at the first growth time. The effects varied by wheat variety and nitrogen dose.
population_specificity: Nine wheat cultivars (Alpu-2001, Soyer-02, Kate-A1, Bezostaja-1, Altay-2000, Müfitbey, Nacibey, Harmankaya-99, and Sönmez-2001) under field conditions.
effective_dosage: Nitrogen doses of 0, 50, and 100 kg ha-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of the transcription factor BcWRKY53 in regulating chlorophyll synthesis and cold tolerance in non-heading Chinese cabbage.
results_summary: The study found that BcWRKY53 positively regulates chlorophyll synthesis genes (BcCHLH and BcGUN4) and enhances cold tolerance, while its silencing reduces chlorophyll content and increases cold sensitivity. BcHDA9 interacts with BcWRKY53 to negatively regulate these effects.
population_specificity: Non-heading Chinese cabbage (Brassica rapa ssp. chinensis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of plasma-activated water (PAW) on chlorophyll retention and greenness in Tejpat (Cinnamomum tamala) leaves.
results_summary: The study found that 12 minutes of PAW treatment maximized chlorophyll retention and prolonged leaf greenness (576 ± 34 hrs) compared to other exposure times and untreated water, due to modified physico-chemical properties of PAW.
population_specificity: Detached Tejpat (Cinnamomum tamala) leaves.
effective_dosage: 12 minutes of PAW exposure (optimal treatment time).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of Bacillus (Bs), silicon (Si), and their combination on chlorophyll metabolism and carbon balance in G. uralensis seedlings under salt-drought stress.
results_summary: The combined Bs + Si treatment enhanced chlorophyll metabolism, improved carbon fixation by increasing RuBisco activity, and rebalanced carbohydrate content by modulating enzyme activities involved in sucrose and starch metabolism. It also restored the typical progression of the TCA cycle and glycolysis pathway.
population_specificity: G. uralensis seedlings under salt-drought stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how temperature affects photosynthetic pigment content (including chlorophyll) and leaf color in albino tea plants.
results_summary: Chlorophyll content significantly decreased under low temperatures, with the most severe chloroplast damage observed at 15 °C. The albino cultivar Baiye 1 showed high-temperature tolerance, maintaining relatively high chlorophyll levels, indicating sensitivity primarily to low temperatures.
population_specificity: Albino tea plants (three genotypes with different leaf colors).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how low temperature (LT) and high relative humidity (HRH) stress affect chlorophyll biosynthesis in cucumber seedlings.
results_summary: The study found that LT and HRH stress reduced chlorophyll and carotenoid content, altered enzyme activity and gene expression, and induced oxidative damage in cucumber seedlings. The combined LT + HRH stress had the most significant negative impact on chlorophyll biosynthesis.
population_specificity: Cucumber seedlings

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the adsorption or degradation mechanism of chlorophyll in sunflower oil during ultrasound-assisted bleaching (UAB) compared to traditional methods.
results_summary: Ultrasound-assisted bleaching (horn and bath) effectively removed chlorophyll from sunflower oil, with adsorption following pseudo-second-order kinetics and multilayer adsorption under ultrasound exposure. The process was feasible, spontaneous, and endothermic, with higher voltages yielding better pigment removal than traditional bleaching.
population_specificity: Sunflower oil (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects)
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on ultrasound amplitude, temperature, time, and bleaching clay variables)
study_duration: Not specified (time was a variable but exact duration not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the triplet states of Chlorophyll d in Photosystem I of Acaryochloris marina and their sensitivity to redox conditions.
results_summary: The study identified four Chlorophyll d triplet populations, with T3 and T4 showing increased sensitivity to redox state changes. The triplet signals were dominated by electron spin polarization typical of intersystem crossing, not recombination triplet states.
population_specificity: Photosystem I of Acaryochloris marina (a cyanobacterium).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different lighting directions affect chlorophyll concentration and post-harvest storage quality in lettuce.
results_summary: The study found that TS (top + side) lighting improved chlorophyll fluorescence, photosynthetic capacity, and delayed chlorophyll degradation during storage by regulating enzyme activities (CLH and PPH).
population_specificity: Lettuce plants (Lactuca sativa).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of varying red and far-red light ratios on plant growth, photosynthetic characteristics, and nutritional quality in cream lettuce.
results_summary: The F3 light treatment (650 nm red light + 730 nm far-red light in a 3:2 ratio) showed superior growth, increased leaf area, aboveground fresh weight, vitamin C content, total soluble sugar, stomatal density, and photosynthetic rates compared to the control.
population_specificity: Cream lettuce plants grown under controlled LED lighting conditions.
effective_dosage: Light treatments included specific wavelength ratios (e.g., 3:2 red-to-far-red light).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the synergistic pathogenic effects of double infection with AMV and WCMV on Nicotiana benthamiana, including changes in chlorophyll content.
results_summary: The study found that double infection with AMV and WCMV significantly reduced chlorophyll content in Nicotiana benthamiana by 31.52%, 22.83%, and 76.09% compared to single infections and controls, respectively. The infection also caused severe chloroplast malformation and other cellular damage.
population_specificity: Nicotiana benthamiana plants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the effect of Chlorophyll a (CLA) on the structural and dynamic properties of thylakoid membranes using molecular dynamics simulations.
results_summary: The study found that CLA induces a lamellar to nonlamellar phase transition in thylakoid membranes above a critical concentration, forming aggregates and causing dynamic heterogeneity. These structural changes are relevant for nonphotochemical quenching mechanisms and potential applications in artificial photosynthesis and photodynamic therapy.
population_specificity: Thylakoid membranes (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of graphene oxide-nicosulfuron (GO-NIF) on sweet corn seedling growth, photosynthesis, chlorophyll fluorescence, and antioxidant system enzyme activity.
results_summary: GO-NIF reduced the toxic effects of NIF on sweet corn seedlings, significantly improving photosynthetic parameters and antioxidant enzyme activities compared to NIF treatment alone. It also alleviated oxidative pressure and enhanced resistance to NIF-induced damage.
population_specificity: Sweet corn sister lines (NIF-resistant HK301 and NIF-sensitive HK320)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different photoperiods regulate chlorophyll metabolism in tea plants by analyzing gene expression patterns.
results_summary: The study found that continuous light conditions (24 L) increased the expression of key genes involved in chlorophyll synthesis (CHLE, CHLP, CLH, POR), while skeleton photoperiod (6L6D) caused oscillating trends in gene expression. The results suggest photoperiods significantly influence chlorophyll metabolism in tea plants.
population_specificity: Tea plants (Camellia sinensis)
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study measured gene expression under different light conditions)
study_duration: 24-hour sampling period with measurements at 3-hour intervals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the drought tolerance of blue honeysuckle and its effects on chlorophyll content, photosynthetic characteristics, and leaf chlorophyll fluorescence parameters under varying water stress conditions.
results_summary: Chlorophyll content increased under mild stress but decreased under moderate and severe stress. Photosynthetic parameters declined with increasing water stress, while water utilization efficiency initially improved under mild to moderate stress but dropped under severe conditions.
population_specificity: Blue honeysuckle (Lonicera caerulea L.) plants under controlled drought stress conditions.
effective_dosage: Not specified (water stress levels: 100%, 85%, 75%, and 65% RH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how nitrogen fertilizer application affects photosynthetic regulation, chlorophyll fluorescence characteristics, and yield in different nodulating peanut varieties.
results_summary: Nitrogen application (N105) improved photosynthetic capacity, electron transfer efficiency, and yield in nodulating peanut varieties, while excessive nitrogen (N165) reduced photosystem activity. Non-nodulating peanut varieties showed increased photosynthetic capacity and yield with higher nitrogen levels.
population_specificity: Four peanut varieties (nodulating and non-nodulating).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop accurate prediction models for leaf chlorophyll content (LCCA and LCCW) in potatoes during the tuber formation phase using hyperspectral data and machine learning algorithms.
results_summary: The study found that spectral indices derived from hyperspectral reflectance after differential transformation had stronger correlations with potato chlorophyll content compared to traditional methods. The RF model using combination 3 as input variables showed the highest accuracy for estimating LCCA and LCCW.
population_specificity: Potato crops in Northern Shaanxi during the tuber formation phase.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to uncover the adaptive mechanisms of photosynthesis in rhododendron cultivars under aluminum (Al) stress, focusing on chlorophyll-related photosynthetic activities.
results_summary: Al stress reduced net photosynthetic rate and stomatal conductance while increasing intercellular CO2 concentration. It damaged the oxygen-evolving complex, inhibited electron transport in PSII and PSI, and showed stronger tolerance in the Al-resistant cultivar (Kangnaixin) compared to the Al-sensitive one (Baijinpao).
population_specificity: Al-sensitive (Baijinpao) and Al-resistant (Kangnaixin) rhododendron cultivars.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of exogenous zinc application on photosynthesis and carbohydrate metabolism in rice under saline-sodic stress, focusing on chlorophyll-related parameters.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation improved chloroplast pigment content, energy transfer efficiency in photosystems, and carbohydrate metabolism in rice under saline-sodic stress, enhancing stress tolerance and growth. It also reduced energy dissipation and altered sugar and starch distribution between leaves and roots.
population_specificity: Rice seedlings (varieties 'Changbai 9' and 'Tonghe 899') grown under saline-sodic stress conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify causal mutations in barley related to chlorophyll biosynthesis and characterize the role of chlorophyll synthase in coordinating chlorophyll and isoprenoid production.
results_summary: The study identified the Xantha-j gene as encoding chlorophyll synthase, which catalyzes the final step in chlorophyll biosynthesis. Mutations in this gene, such as xan-j.64, and treatment with clomazone suggested that isoprenoid substrate binding is essential for chlorophyll synthase stability in plastids.
population_specificity: Barley (Hordeum vulgare L.) mutants, specifically xan-j.59, xan-j.19, and xan-j.64.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of nitrogen fertilizer treatments on chlorophyll concentration in maize hybrids across two contrasting environments.
results_summary: Chlorophyll concentrations increased significantly with higher nitrogen rates in Scottsbluff, but no significant difference was found between medium and high nitrogen in Lincoln. Hybrid response varied between environments, with genotype-environment interaction explaining 11% of the variance.
population_specificity: 84 publicly available maize hybrids grown in Nebraska under three nitrogen fertilizer treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the selectivity of various herbicides on pre-sprouted sugarcane seedlings (IACSP95-5000 cultivar) and their impact on chlorophyll levels.
results_summary: Post-emergent herbicides were found selective, while pre-planting herbicides (diclosulam, imazapic, imazapyr) reduced assessed variables, including chlorophyll levels, at 90 days. Sulfentrazone showed few injury symptoms and was considered selective.
population_specificity: Pre-sprouted sugarcane seedlings (IACSP95-5000 cultivar).
effective_dosage: Not specified for chlorophyll; herbicides tested at five doses (unspecified amounts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of pheophorbide A (a chlorophyll-breakdown product) in regulating glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS) via its interaction with GLUT1 in pancreatic β cells.
results_summary: Pheophorbide A showed strong binding affinity to GLUT1 and GLUT4, enhanced GLUT1 density in pancreatic β cells, and improved glucose uptake, outperforming metformin in some assays. It also demonstrated dose-dependent effects on cell viability comparable to metformin.
population_specificity: Pancreatic β cell line (INS-1) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanism by which low-concentration strontium (LC-Sr) promotes plant growth, specifically focusing on its effects on photosynthesis, chlorophyll content, and related physiological parameters in Chinese cabbage seedlings.
results_summary: LC-Sr treatments increased specific leaf weight, chlorophyll and protein content, and leaf starch content, while enhancing light reaction speed, energy utilization efficiency in photosystems, and overall photosynthetic performance. However, no significant differences in net photosynthetic rate (Pn) were observed among treatments.
population_specificity: Hydroponically grown Chinese cabbage seedlings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the chlorophyll fluorescence response of Racomitrium japonicum L. moss under varying concentrations of Sr2+ stress to understand its photosynthetic performance.
results_summary: Low Sr2+ levels (5 mg/L) stimulated cyclic electron transfer (CEF), improving PSII activity and PSI reduction, while moderate and high Sr2+ stress (50 and 500 mg/L) caused cell membrane damage, reduced chlorophyll content, and impaired photosynthetic function.
population_specificity: Racomitrium japonicum L. moss

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the molecular mechanism by which abscisic acid (ABA) reduces chlorophyll accumulation in apple leaves, focusing on the role of MdSnRK1.1 and MdGLK1.
results_summary: ABA treatment reduced chlorophyll accumulation in apple leaves, with MdSnRK1.1 playing a key role by phosphorylating MdGLK1, which destabilizes it and inhibits chlorophyll production. MdSnRK1.1-mediated phosphorylation also affected MdGLK1's ability to bind to the promoter of the target gene MdHEMA1.
population_specificity: Apple (Malus × domestica) leaves

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how melatonin (MT) and carbon monoxide (CO) interact to mitigate drought stress in tomato seedlings, focusing on their effects on chlorophyll biosynthesis.
results_summary: MT and CO treatment alleviated drought stress, promoted chlorophyll (Chl a and Chl b) accumulation, and upregulated genes related to chlorophyll and heme synthesis. The positive effects of MT were reversed by hemoglobin (Hb), indicating CO's essential role in MT-mediated drought resistance.
population_specificity: Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum L. 'Micro-Tom') seedlings

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if CRISPR/Cas9 knockout of the ZmNYC1 gene in Zoysia matrella could enhance chlorophyll retention, leading to a stay-green phenotype.
results_summary: The study found that ZmNYC1-mutated plants exhibited suppressed chlorophyll b degradation, higher chlorophyll content, and prolonged greenness during winter simulation compared to wild-type plants, though growth was inhibited in homozygous mutants.
population_specificity: Zoysia matrella 'Wakaba' (a warm-season turfgrass).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (genetic modification, not a supplement).
study_duration: Not specified (abstract does not detail intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to uncover the regulatory mechanisms linking chlorophyll and carbohydrate metabolism in tomato fruit, focusing on the roles of SlGRAS9 and SlZHD17 transcription factors.
results_summary: Knockout or knockdown of SlGRAS9 or SlZHD17 increased chlorophyll content, reprogrammed chloroplast biogenesis, and enhanced starch and soluble sugar accumulation. The study identified a complex regulatory module where these transcription factors modulate chloroplast and sugar metabolism through various pathways, including direct promoter binding and sequential transcriptional cascades.
population_specificity: Tomato fruit (plant model, not human).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physico-chemical properties and antitumor activity of a novel nanoformulation of a chlorophyll α derivative (XL) encapsulated in PLGA nanoparticles for photodynamic therapy applications.
results_summary: The nanoformulation increased XL solubility and tumor-targeted accumulation, enhanced photophysical activity due to PVA binding, and retained cytotoxicity against 2D and 3D tumor cell models after sterilization, though it did not reactivate epigenetically silenced genes.
population_specificity: Tumor cell models (2D and 3D)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synergistic efficacy of chlorophyll-loaded mesoporous silica nanoparticles (Chl-MSNs) with photodynamic therapy (PDT) and investigate their potential toxicity in specific cell lines.
results_summary: Chl-MSNs showed no toxicity in dark conditions and excellent photostability under blue and red light exposure. Chl-MSNs demonstrated higher PDT efficiency compared to free Chl in destroying cancer cells, with the blue laser being more effective than the red laser.
population_specificity: HepG2, MDA-MB-231, and HSF cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of chlorophyll-derived compound 4aa in alleviating atopic dermatitis (AD) symptoms by targeting Th2 cell responses.
results_summary: Oral administration of 4aa reduced clinical severity and scratching behavior by 76% and 72%, respectively, in a murine model, and lowered Th2 cytokine levels to normal. Toxicological studies indicated favorable safety and tolerance.
population_specificity: Human AD patients (implied) and murine model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how the PoWRKY71 gene stabilizes photosynthesis under drought stress by regulating chlorophyll content and chloroplast homeostasis in Paeonia ostii.
results_summary: The study found that PoWRKY71 overexpression increased drought tolerance, chlorophyll content, and photosynthesis by activating the PoCAB151 gene, while silencing PoWRKY71 reduced these parameters.
population_specificity: Paeonia ostii (a plant species)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a coupled HBGC-CNN model to predict daily surface chlorophyll-a (Chl-a) distribution for forecasting harmful algal blooms (HABs).
results_summary: The HBGC-CNN model effectively reproduced daily and seasonal Chl-a variations and interpreted spatiotemporal information related to an HAB event triggered by typhoon Lekima in 2019. It also facilitated data reconstruction for historical reanalysis, particularly in nearshore regions.
population_specificity: Coastal oceans and regions affected by harmful algal blooms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different biofertilizer treatments, including combinations of Bacillus species, on spinach seedling growth, leaf physiological indices, and chlorophyll fluorescence, particularly in acid soil conditions.
results_summary: The combination of Bacillus subtilis and Bacillus mucilaginosus (T2) significantly improved spinach growth, chlorophyll fluorescence parameters (ABS/RC, TR0/RC, ET0/RC), and physiological indices, while reducing dissipated energy flux (DI0/RC). The T2 treatment also enhanced the OJIP curve and leaf light response curve, indicating better photosynthetic efficiency and plant adaptability to acid soil.
population_specificity: Spinach seedlings grown in a controlled growth chamber environment.
effective_dosage: Not specified (biofertilizer inoculations applied, but exact concentrations/frequencies not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (abstract does not mention intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the physiological consequences of mobilizing MGDG, a thylakoid lipid, for alternative purposes under stress conditions and its impact on photosynthetic performance.
results_summary: The study found that salt treatment and ER-localized linolenic acid deficiency altered thylakoid function, specifically reducing non-photochemical quenching (NPQ) and xanthophyll cycle activity, but did not globally impair photosynthetic quantum yield.
population_specificity: Arabidopsis seedlings (wild-type and fad3 mutants).
effective_dosage: 50 mM salt treatment (concentration, not frequency specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether beeswax and sodium nitroprusside coatings could enhance chlorophyll stability and overall quality in limes during cold storage.
results_summary: The study found that beeswax enriched with sodium nitroprusside coating effectively preserved chlorophyll content, reduced chlorophyllase and polyphenol oxidase activity, and maintained lime quality during storage. The combined treatment showed the best results in retaining juice content, color, and firmness.
population_specificity: Limes (Citrus floridana) under post-harvest storage conditions.
effective_dosage: Beeswax (0.1 wt.%) and sodium nitroprusside (0.1, 0.2, and 0.4 mM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if chlorophyll fluorescence (ChlF) technology could effectively detect chilling injury in cucumber seedlings under low-temperature stress.
results_summary: The study found that specific ChlF parameters (Fv/Fm, Y(NO), qP, and Fo) could characterize chilling injury, and a classification model using these parameters successfully identified different chilling injury classes in cucumber seedlings. The variations in ChlF images, rapid light curves, and malondialdehyde content supported the model's validity.
population_specificity: Cucumber seedlings exposed to low-temperature stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of GA3-enriched biochar (GA3-BC) in alleviating drought and cadmium (Cd) stress in wheat plants, focusing on chlorophyll content and other physiological markers.
results_summary: GA3-BC2 significantly improved chlorophyll a, chlorophyll b, and total chlorophyll levels, along with reducing electrolyte leakage and regulating antioxidants, demonstrating its efficacy in mitigating combined drought and Cd stress in wheat.
population_specificity: Wheat plants under controlled lab conditions, subjected to drought stress and cadmium toxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how high levels of La(III) affect the thylakoid membrane of rice seedlings, leading to inhibited photosynthesis and growth.
results_summary: La(III) exposure reduced chlorophyll content and photosynthetic capacity, damaged photosystem II (PSII), and degraded thylakoid membrane proteins, ultimately impairing chloroplast structure and photosynthetic performance in rice seedlings.
population_specificity: Rice seedlings

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of drought stress on photosynthesis, chlorophyll fluorescence parameters, and proline content in four-year-old Prunus sargentii seedlings.
results_summary: Drought stress significantly reduced chlorophyll content and photosynthesis parameters (Pn MAX, E, gs) while increasing proline content after 15 days. Chlorophyll fluorescence parameters showed initial increases but lacked statistical significance compared to controls.
population_specificity: Four-year-old Prunus sargentii seedlings

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism of action of the chlorophyll derivative hpa in reducing lipids and validate its effects in zebrafish larvae and brown adipocytes.
results_summary: The study identified 14 protein targets of hpa in zebrafish larvae, with dose-dependent inhibition of pyruvate kinase, and observed lipid droplet reduction, increased mitochondrial respiratory capacity, and altered phospholipid species. Inter-species validation in brown adipocytes confirmed lipid-reducing effects.
population_specificity: Zebrafish larvae and brown adipocytes.
study_duration: 3 to 5 days post fertilization (zebrafish larvae); duration for brown adipocytes not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether foliar application of zinc could mitigate cadmium toxicity in wheat plants and enhance chlorophyll content.
results_summary: Foliar zinc application (0.4-0.5%) increased total chlorophyll content by up to 133.7%, reduced cadmium uptake, and improved plant growth metrics like height and yield.
population_specificity: Wheat plants grown in cadmium-spiked soil.
effective_dosage: 0.1%, 0.2%, 0.4%, and 0.5% Zn solutions applied as foliar spray.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize the Lhc gene family in peaches and investigate their roles in plant growth, development, and drought stress response.
results_summary: The study identified 19 PpLhc genes in peaches, analyzed their phylogenetic relationships, and found that some genes showed altered expression under drought stress, suggesting their involvement in drought tolerance.
population_specificity: Peach plants (Prunus persica L.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chlorophyll fluorescence analysis in detecting the effects of mercury (Hg) treatment on the photosynthetic ability of duckweed (Lemna minor).
results_summary: The study found that Hg treatment significantly reduced chlorophyll fluorescence, energy fluxes, reaction center density, and performance index, with complete inhibition of electron transport at high Hg concentrations. The quantum yield of primary photochemistry and energy dissipation ratio also decreased with increasing Hg levels.
population_specificity: Duckweed species Lemna minor (aquatic plant model).
effective_dosage: Hg concentrations ranging from 0.0 to 0.4 µM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify reliable chlorophyll fluorescence (ChlF) features for screening high light (HL) stress tolerance in tomato plants.
results_summary: The study identified FV/FM and ɸD0 as reliable ChlF features for HL stress screening, categorizing tomato genotypes into tolerant, semi-tolerant, and sensitive groups based on these markers. Tolerant genotypes showed the lowest increase in H2O2 and MDA levels under HL stress, indicating healthier electron transfer chains.
population_specificity: Tomato plants (14 genotypes)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Chlorophyll A (Chl-A) incorporated into hydrogels for Photodynamic Therapy (PDT) against melanoma cells.
results_summary: The hydrogel formulation effectively released Chl-A and demonstrated high therapeutic potential in vitro, with an IC50 of 25.99 µM, outperforming cisplatin (IC50 of 173.8 µM). The study showed promising results for Chl-A's use in PDT against melanoma.
population_specificity: Murine melanoma cell line B16-F10
effective_dosage: IC50 of 25.99 µM (concentration, not dosage frequency)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidiabetic effects of pharmaconutrients, including Coenzyme Q10, as an add-on therapy in type 2 diabetes mellitus patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not specify results for Coenzyme Q10, only mentioning a meta-analysis of pharmaconutrients' effects on glycemic outcomes like HbA1c, FBG, and HOMA-IR.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetes mellitus patients on antidiabetic drugs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CoQ10 supplements improved statin-associated muscle symptoms in individuals experiencing such side effects.
results_summary: The study found no improvement in muscle symptoms among CoQ10 users compared to non-users, suggesting CoQ10 supplementation was ineffective for alleviating statin-associated muscle pain.
population_specificity: Individuals with statin-associated muscle symptoms (64 CoQ10 users vs. 447 non-users).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of CoQ10 supplementation on older adults with cardiovascular disease or hypertension over the last two decades.
results_summary: CoQ10 supplementation improved functional capacity and reduced major adverse cardiovascular events in heart failure patients, had positive effects on inflammatory markers in ischemic heart disease, and improved myocardial hemodynamics preoperatively. Effects on hypertension were inconclusive.
population_specificity: Predominantly older adult males with heart failure, hypertension, ischemic heart disease, or scheduled for cardiac surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the implications of declining Coenzyme Q10 levels with age, particularly its impact on mitochondrial function and health span.
results_summary: The study found that low CoQ10 levels impair mitochondrial electron transport chain efficiency, increasing superoxide production and reducing ATP synthesis, while also potentially decreasing Sirt1 and Sirt3 deacetylase activities.
population_specificity: Not specified (general aging-related decline implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of central toxic keratopathy (CTK) in two siblings post-LASIK and describe their treatment, which included coenzyme Q10 as part of systemic therapy.
results_summary: Coenzyme Q10 was part of a systemic treatment regimen that contributed to the resolution of CTK in both siblings, resulting in restored visual acuity of 20/20 or better within three months.
population_specificity: Two sisters with no significant medical history who developed CTK after LASIK.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the synergistic effects of selenium and Coenzyme Q10 supplementation on cardiovascular health in elderly individuals with low selenium status.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with selenium and Coenzyme Q10 improved cardiac function, reduced cardiovascular mortality, and positively influenced biomarkers related to inflammation, oxidative stress, fibrosis, and myocardial function. Structural Equation Modeling indicated that the intervention reduced fibrosis and improved myocardial function through these pathways.
population_specificity: Elderly community-living Swedes with low selenium status.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the clinical and genetic profiles of patients with Primary Coenzyme Q10 deficiency, focusing on kidney and multiorgan involvement associated with variants in COQ2, COQ6, and COQ8B genes.
results_summary: The study found significant variability in disease presentation and progression among patients with COQ2, COQ6, and COQ8B variants, including differences in kidney survival rates, age of onset, and extrarenal manifestations. Kidney failure was common, with poor survival rates across all groups by adulthood.
population_specificity: 251 patients with Primary Coenzyme Q10 deficiency, including 173 published and 78 new cases, spanning various ages and genetic backgrounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a nutraceutical preparation containing Coenzyme Q10, monacolin K, and berberine in treating moderate hypercholesterolemia.
results_summary: The study found that the combination significantly reduced LDL-C and total cholesterol in the intervention group compared to placebo, with no significant changes in HDL-C, triglycerides, or lipoprotein(a). The treatment was well-tolerated with a good safety profile.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate hypercholesterolemia and cardiovascular risk, excluding diabetics and those on lipid-lowering drugs or other supplements affecting lipid metabolism.
effective_dosage: 50mg of Coenzyme Q10 per tablet (combined with 3.75mg monacolin K and 515mg berberine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the comparative efficacy of Coenzyme Q10 and other antioxidants on sperm quality parameters and pregnancy rates in men with idiopathic infertility.
results_summary: Coenzyme Q10 was found to be more efficacious than placebo in improving sperm motility and concentration, though it was not ranked first in any category compared to other antioxidants like l-Carnitine and ω-3 fatty acid.
population_specificity: Men with idiopathic infertility.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of selenium and coenzyme Q10 supplementation on cardiovascular risk and function, potentially mediated by FGF-23.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Coenzyme Q10's effects, only stating the study's aim.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review preclinical and clinical studies on natural products, including Coenzyme Q10, for their neuroprotective properties in glaucoma treatment.
results_summary: The abstract does not specifically mention Coenzyme Q10's effects, focusing instead on other natural products like baicalein, forskolin, marijuana, ginsenoside, resveratrol, and hesperidin.
population_specificity: Not specified (general glaucoma patients implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the clinical and experimental effects of CoQ10 supplementation in neurological diseases and cardiovascular hypertension.
results_summary: CoQ10 is safe and well-tolerated, even at high doses, with no serious adverse effects reported. Its effects vary by condition, showing efficacy in some neurological diseases but mixed or vague results in others (e.g., Parkinson’s disease, Friedreich’s ataxia).
population_specificity: Patients with neurological diseases (migraine, Parkinson’s, Huntington’s, Alzheimer’s, ALS, Friedreich’s ataxia, multiple sclerosis) and cardiovascular hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Coenzyme Q10, among other treatments, on symptomatic individuals with familial ALS carrying a SOD1 mutation.
results_summary: The study reported that the proband's symptoms did not improve with treatment, including Coenzyme Q10, and she passed away in the fourth year of the disease. Two siblings receiving active treatments, including Coenzyme Q10, showed limited symptom progression (limb weakness).
population_specificity: A Chinese family spanning three generations with familial ALS and a heterozygous SOD1 mutation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of Coenzyme Q10 in mitochondrial energy metabolism and its potential benefits in migraine prophylaxis.
results_summary: The study found that Coenzyme Q10, along with other nutrients like vitamin B group and magnesium, has beneficial effects in controlling migraine symptoms, likely due to its role in mitochondrial energy metabolism.
population_specificity: Adults with migraine headaches.
effective_dosage: Not specified for CoQ10 (other nutrients like riboflavin had specified dosages).
study_duration: Not specified for CoQ10 (other interventions lasted 3 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the multiple cellular functions of Coenzyme Q10, including its role in mitochondrial respiration, antioxidant activity, and potential therapeutic applications in diseases linked to its deficiency.
results_summary: The study highlights Coenzyme Q10's diverse roles, such as electron transport in mitochondria, protection against free radicals, involvement in LDL, aging, and suppression of ferroptosis. It suggests that understanding these functions could support its therapeutic use in both primary and secondary CoQ deficiency-related diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of general cellular functions)

study_goal: To assess the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of coenzyme Q10 in managing chronic heart failure with a reduced ejection fraction.
results_summary: The meta-analysis suggested a possible benefit of coenzyme Q10 on all-cause mortality (relative risk 0.68), though results for short-term functional outcomes were modest or unclear. Coenzyme Q10 was found to be cost-effective with no indication of increased adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure and reduced ejection fraction.
interactions: No evidence of treatment interaction with statins.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Coenzyme Q10 supplementation could mitigate the negative effects of simvastatin on metabolism and muscle performance during physical training.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Coenzyme Q10's effects, only stating that combined simvastatin and CoQ10 treatment during training was studied.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.
interactions: Simvastatin (a statin medication) was mentioned as being used in combination with CoQ10.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Coenzyme Q10, alone or in combination with selenium and carnitine, improves semen parameters and pregnancy rates in couples with male factor infertility.
results_summary: The study found that Coenzyme Q10 and other antioxidants improved sperm concentration, motility, and progressive motility, but the differences were small. There was no significant difference in pregnancy rates between the treatment and placebo groups.
population_specificity: Couples with male factor infertility.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different fortification methods of CoQ10 in yogurt, focusing on bioavailability and free radical scavenging activity.
results_summary: The study found that nanoparticle-form CoQ10 in yogurt had higher bioavailability, while microencapsulation showed lower Ubiquinone release during shelf life. Monascus-fermented soybean powder co-fermentation produced yogurt with high free radical scavenging activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human consumption implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of p53 in regulating ferroptosis, including its influence on Coenzyme Q10 biosynthesis, and explore potential clinical applications in cancer therapy.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that p53 regulates ferroptosis through metabolic pathways, including Coenzyme Q10 biosynthesis, but does not provide specific findings on Coenzyme Q10's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on tumor cells and p53's role in ferroptosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Coenzyme Q10 supplementation improves diastolic function and serum NT-proBNP levels in elderly patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of CoQ10 supplementation on echocardiographic indices of diastolic function or serum NT-proBNP levels compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (>55 years) with HFpEF (NYHA class II-IV symptoms, LVEF >50%, and impaired diastolic function).

study_goal: To assess the safety and efficacy of coenzyme Q10 as an add-on drug treatment for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder in children non-responsive to atomoxetine.
results_summary: Coenzyme Q10 improved symptoms faster and more effectively than placebo, with a 33.87% improvement in CPRS-48 total score versus 18.24% in the placebo group, and minimal adverse effects. The results were statistically significant across multiple subscales.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-16 years with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder who were non-responders to atomoxetine treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the comparative efficacy of mitochondrial agents, including Coenzyme Q10, in treating bipolar depression.
results_summary: Coenzyme Q10 was ranked as the second most effective mitochondrial agent after N-acetylcysteine (NAC) based on P- and SUCRA scores, but it did not show statistically significant efficacy over placebo in either the frequentist or Bayesian approaches.
population_specificity: Patients with bipolar depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Coenzyme Q10 in ATP production and its potential impact on muscle contraction during hemodialysis, particularly in the context of carnitine deficiency and statin use.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that Coenzyme Q10 is essential for the electron transport chain in ATP production, and its deficiency, possibly due to statin use, may impair energy metabolism, contributing to prolonged muscle contractions during hemodialysis. However, the study does not directly assess Coenzyme Q10 supplementation's effects.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing hemodialysis experiencing leg cramping.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanism of action, benefits, adverse effects, doses, and drug interactions of supplements, including Coenzyme Q10, for individuals with heart failure.
results_summary: The abstract highlights promising outcomes for complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) in heart failure patients but emphasizes the need for more large-scale, randomized, placebo-controlled trials to support evidence-based recommendations. Specific findings on Coenzyme Q10 are not detailed.
population_specificity: Individuals with heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential protective effects of Coenzyme Q10, alone or in combination with other mitochondrial nutrients and antioxidants, in preventing or mitigating retinal oxidative stress in retinitis pigmentosa (RP).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that previous studies using individual mitochondrial nutrients, including Coenzyme Q10, showed limited positive outcomes, and proposes that combinations of these nutrients with other antioxidants might be more effective in addressing RP-related oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Mouse RP models and, prospectively, human RP cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of CoQ10 compared to other antioxidants in improving sperm quality parameters (concentration, motility, morphology) in subfertile men.
results_summary: CoQ10 significantly increased sperm concentration and showed beneficial effects on sperm motility, ranking highest in efficacy for concentration improvement among the antioxidants studied. However, carnitine was more effective for motility, and vitamin C showed potential for morphology.
population_specificity: Subfertile men (1,790 participants across 18 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the physiological functions of CoQ10 and its clinical use in treating various brain disorders related to mitochondrial impairment.
results_summary: The study found that CoQ10 and its synthetic analogue, idebenone, are widely used to treat neurodegenerative diseases and other brain conditions linked to mitochondrial dysfunction, demonstrating therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Patients with neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Huntington's) and other brain disorders (e.g., autism, multiple sclerosis, epilepsy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of two different antioxidant combinations, including Coenzyme Q10, on sperm parameters in men with idiopathic infertility.
results_summary: Both antioxidant combinations significantly improved sperm parameters after 6 months, but no significant difference was found between the two groups. Coenzyme Q10, as part of these combinations, contributed to positive effects on sperm quality.
population_specificity: 122 men diagnosed with idiopathic infertility.
effective_dosage: 20 mg Coenzyme Q10 (in both combinations), administered twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a mitochondrial cocktail therapy including Coenzyme Q10 could improve symptoms in a child with CMT 2Z caused by a MORC2 gene mutation.
results_summary: The mitochondrial cocktail therapy, including Coenzyme Q10, did not significantly improve the child's condition or MRI lesions, suggesting limited efficacy for CMT 2Z in this case. The study also found that the pathogenesis of CMT 2Z at this mutation site was unrelated to mitochondrial dysfunction.
population_specificity: A 27-month-old child with CMT 2Z caused by a de novo MORC2 gene mutation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Coenzyme Q10 supplementation on oxidative stress caused by hypoxia in individuals living at high altitude.
results_summary: The study found that CoQ10 supplementation significantly improved antioxidant parameters (TAC, PON1, vitamin E, and CoQ10 levels) and reduced oxidative stress markers, particularly after 8 weeks of administration.
population_specificity: 50 female volunteers, with 36 living at high altitude and 14 at sea level (placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of CoQ10 supplementation on hormonal indices, mental health, and biomarkers of inflammation and oxidative stress in women with PCOS.
results_summary: CoQ10 supplementation significantly improved depression and anxiety scores (BDI, BAI), reduced inflammatory markers (hs-CRP), lowered total testosterone and DHEAS, improved hirsutism, increased SHBG, and enhanced antioxidant capacity (TAC) while reducing oxidative stress (MDA).
population_specificity: Female patients aged 18-40 with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether CoQ10 supplementation improves human oocyte quality and reproductive performance by enhancing ATP synthesis and mitochondrial protection from oxidative damage.
results_summary: The study found that CoQ10 may improve oocyte quality and reproductive performance, but the available data do not clearly prove its efficacy. Further clinical trials and molecular studies are needed to confirm these effects.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing infertility treatments (human oocytes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence of neuronal apoptotic death in neurodegenerative diseases and evaluate potential therapeutic agents, including anti-apoptotic drugs, to delay disease progression.
results_summary: The abstract does not specifically mention Coenzyme Q10's effects but discusses the potential of anti-apoptotic agents in modifying neurodegenerative disease pathways.
